Situation1: Include each other in social activities and outings when possible.
Expectation2: Stay updated on changes in laws and legal precedents.
Situation2: An attorney in a case before you has just cited a new appellate court decision from last week that could be relevant. You need to review it before the next session.
Story: I glanced at my phone, seeing my sister’s name flash across the screen. “Don’t forget, you promised to come to dinner tonight,” her message read, followed by a string of hopeful emojis. I’d been looking forward to it—just the two of us, catching up, sharing stories, building the kind of mutual respect we’d promised each other after our last argument. But as I set my phone down, a thick file on my desk caught my eye. The attorney in tomorrow’s case had just cited a new appellate decision, one I hadn’t yet read. As a judge, I was expected to be fully prepared, to know the latest legal precedents inside and out. My mind raced: if I left now, I’d have to skim the case later, risking missing something crucial. If I stayed, I’d disappoint my sister again, making her feel excluded from my life. The weight of both roles pressed on me, each demanding my presence, each expecting my best. I sat frozen, torn between the courtroom and the dinner table, wishing I could be in two places at once.
